catalyst.source: This work presents the design and preparation of three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) TiO 2 -supported Au nanoparticles with enhanced visible-light-responsive properties for the application in carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) photoreduction.
catalyst.context: This work presents the design and preparation of three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) TiO 2 -supported Au nanoparticles with enhanced visible-light-responsive properties for the application in carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) photoreduction.The 3DOM TiO 2 support was prepared using a colloidal crystal template (CCT) method.A series of photocatalysts of TiO 2 -supported Au nanoparticles with uniform sizes were successfully synthesized by the facile method of gas bubbling-assisted membrane reduction (GBMR).These photocatalysts were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) analysis of nitrogen adsorption isotherm, photoluminescence spectra (PL), and the surface photovoltage (SPV) technique.All the catalysts possess well-defined 3DOM structures, which are highly ordered and interconnected with one another by small pore windows, and the Au nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed and supported on the inner wall of the uniform macropores.The slow light effect of the 3DOM structure can enhance absorption efficiency of solar irradiation.And the introduction of Au nanoparticles can effectively extend the spectral response from UV to visible region owing to Au surface plasmon resonance (SPR), and it is favorable for enhancing the separation of photoinduced electron-hole pairs.3DOM Au/TiO 2 photocatalysts exhibit high catalytic activity for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O to CH 4 under visible illumination.

catalyst.context: The poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) colloidal crystaltemplating methods were used for the preparation of 3DOM titanium dioxide using tetrabutyl titanate as precursor solution.In a typical calcination, the temperature-rising rate was 1 C min -1 from room temperature to 600 C. The dried sample was calcined at 600 C for 5 h to remove the CCT at an air flow of 80 ml min -1 in a tube furnace.Finally, a 3DOM TiO 2 support was obtained 16. The photocatalysts of 3DOM TiO 2 -supported Au nanoparticles (3DOM Au n /TiO 2 , where the weight ratio of Au to TiO 2 is n/100) were synthesized by the GBMR technique which is described in detail in our previous reports 171819. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a diffractometer (Shimadzu XRD 6000) using Cu K ( 0.15406 nm) radiation with a Nickel filter operating at 40 kV and 10 mA in the 2 range of 10-80 with a step of 0.02 /0.2 s.The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas of the powders were measured by nitrogen adsorption in an Autosorb iQ/ASiQwin Quantachrome Gas Sorption Analyzer (U.S.A).The UV-vis DRS experiments were performed in the range of 200-800 nm on a UV-vis spectrophotometer (Hitachi U-4100) and BaSO 4 was used as a reference.The TEM and HRTEM images were obtained by a JEOl JEM-2100 electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.The SEM images were examined with scanning electron microscopy of FEI Quanta 200F at an accelerating voltage of 30 kV.X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer PHI-1600 ESCA spectrometer using Mg Ka (h 1253.6eV) X-ray source.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the as-prepared samples were measured using a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer.The metal ions were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer.The surface photovoltage (SPV) measurement was performed with a lock-in based SPV measurement system at room temperature and in air atmosphere. The activity measurements for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O were carried out in a gas-closed circulation system 19.A Xe lamp (300 W) purchased from Perfect Light Co.Light with a 420 nm UV-cutoff filter was used as the visible-light source.The reaction products were analyzed by using an on-line gas chromatograph (GC-9560; HuaAiSePu Corp., China).The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O was typically carried out at 298 K for 480 min in each run and samples were continually taken from the reaction cell at given intervals (40 min) for quantitative analysis based on the external standard by using a calibration curve.

Fig. 3 shows the TEM and HRTEM images of 3DOM Au 4 /TiO 2 catalysts.The 3DOM structure with overlapped pores can be clearly observed after loading Au nanoparticles.The pore sizes of 3DOM Au 4 /TiO 2 catalysts are 320 20 nm, and the voids are interconnected through open windows of 90 5 nm in diameter, which is in agreement with their SEM observations.The walls of the macroporous samples are crystalline by selected area electron diffraction (SAED) (inset in Fig. 3A), which the characteristic SAED rings of the TiO 2 support from inside to outside are indexed as (101), (004), and (200) planes of a tetragonal structure, respectively.It is in accordance with the result of XRD characterization.As shown in Fig. 3B, the Au nanoparticles precipitated on the inner wall of the 3DOM TiO 2 support can also be clearly observed in the HRTEM image, on which all Au particles are highly dispersed and uniform in size.The magnification of Au particles in the inset image of Fig. 3B shows that the spherical gold particles locate on the surface of the TiO 2 support, and the clear lattice fringes were measured to be 2.3 and 1. Fig. 4 shows the representative nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of 3DOM TiO 2 and Au n /TiO 2 catalysts.It can be noted that a nearly linear correlation between the absorbed volume and relative pressure is observed under the low pressure in the relative pressure (p/p o ) range of 0-0.4,which is attributed to unrestricted monolayer-multilayer adsorption.The isotherms of the samples exhibited a type III isotherm with a type H3 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure p/p o range of 0.8-1.0, a small type H2 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure p/p o range of 0.4-0.8,suggesting the existence of macropores and textural mesopores within the skeletons of macropores.Surface areas and pore volumes of 3DOM TiO 2 and Au n /TiO 2 catalysts were in the ranges of 36-45 m 2 g -1 and 0.122-0.164cm 3 /g, respectively.In addition, the average size of textural mesopore estimated according to the BJH pore sizes of the samples were in the range of 8-10 nm. samples.As shown in Fig. 5A, the binding energies of Ti 2p 1/2 and Ti 2p 3/2 in both TiO 2 and Au n /TiO 2 are about 464.4 and 458.3 eV, respectively.Meanwhile, the presence of Au nanoparticles in composites shows no significant influence on the Ti 2p binding energies.These values, along with the sharp features of Ti 2p XPS spectra, indicate that the cations in pure TiO 2 are all in the Ti 4 state 22.Fig. 5B shows the O 1s XPS spectra and the deconvolution results of all samples.The XPS spectra of O 1s are wide and asymmetric, indicating that at least two kinds of oxygen species are present on the surface, which can be recognized by resolving XPS curves.The O 1s binding energies are located at 529.5, 531.1, and 532.7 eV.The peak with lower binding energy is assigned to lattice oxygen (O 2-) in the metal oxides, the next is ascribed to chemisorbed oxygen or/and bonded oxygen species (O 2 2-or O -), and the third peak at the highest binding energy is due to surface oxygen by hydroxyl species and/or weakly adsorbed oxygen species (O 2 -) on the surface 23,24.When Au NPs were loaded on TiO 2 , the O ads /O latt molar ratio increased remarkably, and the highest O ads /O latt molar ratio was achieved on Au 8 /3DOM TiO 2 .The highest concentration of chemisorbed oxygen for 3DOM Au 8 /TiO 2 catalysts can be attributed to the increasing density of oxygen vacancy.The XPS spectra in the Au 4f region of 3DOM Au/TiO 2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5C.Deconvolution of the Au spectra indicates that both metallic (Au 0 ) and ionic gold species (Au and Au 3 ) are present in supported Au nanoparticle catalysts 25,26.It is deduced that the appearance of ionic gold species (Au and Au 3 ) may be derived from the increased amount of surface active oxygen species (O 2 2-, O
